results.title: All our tomorrows
results.creator_credit: Rosalind Eduemon, Rosalind Farber and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
This film examines an integrated community care program in Canada which allows older people to remain in the community as long as possible and lead full, happy and productive lives.

results.title: The Act of abortion
results.creator_credit: Terence O'Reilly, Shirley Fisher and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
An examination of the difficulties which surround women who want and those who perform the act of abortion. The 1967 Abortion Act in Britain is to be reviewed. This well intentioned legislation has resulted in illogicalities whereby some private abortionists are profitting while the National Health Service is sometimes reluctant to help.

results.title: Dispensing a cure
results.brief_description: One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region. Ian Darling and Doug McColl have each practised pharmacy for over forty years in the Warracknabeal district. In this film they recall the era when most drugs were hand-made on the premises, generally from raw materials. Ian also tells of the mysterious medicine jar labelled ‘ADT’ and of an old-fashioned coin-operated machine for a self administered electric shock.

results.title: Marsupial memories
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the 6 works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region.
Allan Vaughan tells the story of a funny looking stuffed kangaroo housed at the Murtoa museum. He recalls how, as a child, he used to visit the kangaroo when it was a pet belonging to his uncle. He tells how his uncle used to box with this kangaroo and also relates the story of how the animal came to end up as a taxidermic display.

results.title: The Finest of wheat
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the 6 works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region.
The late Don Wurfel was a farmer with an unusually keen interest in wheat breeding and the trialing of new crops for improved yields. Part of his legacy is an amazing collection of over 1500 grain varieties, most of which are housed at Wheatlands museum in Warracknabeal. In this film, Don’s son Ian talks about his father’s obsessive interest in new grain varieties and explains the importance of crop trialing for dryland farmers.

results.title: Malcolm McKinnon: 6 films for MAP at ACMI
results.brief_description: A collection of six short documentary films from an ongoing project between the filmmaker, Malcolm McKinnon, and small museums in the Wimmera farming region of Victoria. They comprise of local stories told by local people from such areas as Warracknabeal, Rainbow, Murtoa, Brim and Coromby.
results.title_for_label: Malcolm McKinnon: 6 films for MAP at ACMI

group_works.title: Disappeared racecourses of north west Victoria

results.title: Disappeared racecourses of north west Victoria
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the 6 works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region.
Ian Fisher was a champion jockey in north west Victoria in the 1930s and ‘40s. In this film he and his brother Trenfield recall the tracks they raced on across this region, most of which have now disappeared. Standing on the site of the old Rainbow racecourse, Ian tells the story of winning the Rainbow Cup in 1937 and remembers the people who “made racing” in that era.

group.title: Malcolm McKinnon: 6 films for MAP at ACMI

results.title: Coromby - every Monday night
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the 6 works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region.
The Coromby Brass Band is a group of farmers who come together every Monday night to practice in a draughty hall beside the wheat silos on a back road outside the small town of Murtoa. Formed in 1891, the band is the oldest continuously active brass band in Australia. Many members have been involved for decades - in some cases, their fathers and grandfathers played in the band before them. In this film, members of the band talk about what keeps them turning up at the hall “every Monday night”.

results.title: A Bulldog man
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the 6 works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region.
Lanz Bulldog tractors have been a big part of life in the Bolwell family since the 1930’s. Tim Bolwell has inherited his father’s collection of almost 30 Bulldog tractors, as well as an encyclopedic knowledge of the history and mechanics of these unusual machines. In this film, Tim explains the attraction of the Bulldog and its historical importance for many farmers in the Wimmera region.

results.title: Mugging: a case study in communication
results.creator_credit: Victor Lockwood and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Making Sense of Society”.
Looks at the press coverage of “mugging” to illustrate some points about the social nature of mass communications. Brings together and connects the two themes of communication and crime. Stuart Hall, of the University of Birmingham looks at and discusses these issues.
